comments.commentBody: Does he even listen to his advisors? I don't remember Bush making rash statements like Romney's.

Rima, I think you may just have highlighted the core worry ahead of this election; too many people don't remember Bush. Let me refresh your memory:

"Major combat operations in Iraq have ended. In the battle of Iraq, the United States and our allies have prevailed." - May 1, 2003

"Bring 'em on" - July 2, 2003

"I will not withdraw, even if Laura and Barney are the only ones supporting me." - talking to key Republicans about Iraq, as quoted by Bob Woodward

"The British government has learned that Saddam Hussein recently sought significant quantities of uranium from Africa" - Jan 28, 2003

Mitt Romney has the same advisors on the Middle East that George W. Bush had. Romney's advisors are the exact same people who sent us to war Iraq. Do we want another George W. Bush? Do we want another war in the Middle East?
Any two of Wondo, Boyd and Jozy will suffice.
I hope you didn't also ask for Avenue of the Americas.
RR was a beautiful shell of a man.  Seem familiar?

Unless there's a Hollywood comeback story in the very near future (next week's debate) the show's over.  If the polls say it's close, then with the Big Red Machine Vote Suppression effort (from the Scalia gang on down) it's stock up for tribulation time.
Keep ignoring impressions with nonsense references to facts and you will miss the reality of the situation.

I'll second your pionts by adding that one of the bedrock Vermont values is the worth of the individual.  So many excellent ideas and inventions have come out of Vermont--from George Perkins Marsh, conservationist, to John Deere and many, many others.  Here in Vermont there was the elbow room and tranquillity to be who you were, try things out, use your smarts and ingenuity for the good of the community.  If there was a better way to do something the Vermonter would discover it.  That ethic still prevails here.  We do not suffer from group-think.

*Of course* all scientific research uses terms such as 'likely' and 'very likely'.
It's science. That's how the scientific method works and that's how it has always worked. Every first year science student is taught this.
Science deals in "The balance of probability" and "Beyond reasonable doubt" not "Proof".
Science cant even say for 'certain' that the sun will rise tommorrow.
Making impossible demands for 'proof' merely reveals that you don't understand even the basics of the scientific method or - more likely - that you do understand the first basics of the scientific mehod but are attempting to sow doubt where none exits.
Standard tactic of the...er.."skepticks". No-one is going to fall for that level of nonsense - unless they want to.
When you harbor terrorists, one should not be surprised when things go boom.

Re: Linda
Yours is my favorite comment thus far - I am always shocked to see the confidence and arrogance that the proponents of scientific thinking seem to exhibit, in issues ranging from genetically modified foods, to stem cell research, to nuclear energy - it's either you believe wholeheartedly in "science", or you are irrational, backwards, narrow-minded, a Luddite - there is no room for nuance, ethics, consideration of the fact that humans are still humans, with their desires and vices along with their virtues. We have seen with other great discoveries the potential for harm, I am surprised the potential for harm is not brought up in these columns - but how could it be, when one will be shot down for being backwards and a barrier to progress.
And I myself am a lover and student of the sciences, if that means anything.

indian,  what u claim is true of all groups.  u single out our Prophet for your own reasons.  what is the name of the hindu nationalist party?  JHU?  let me qoute Qur'an to correct ur errors.Islam never tolerates unprovoked aggression from is own side.  muslims are commanded in the Qur'an not to begin hostilities, violate the rights of others or harm the innocent.  war is waged only to defend the religous community against oppression and persecution, because the Qur'an says that persecution is worse than slaughter Qur'an 2:190  the violence you speak of is applicable to all human groupings.  look at the so called buddhists of sri lanka.  so brother get off your high horse.  you and your people are not innocents.

Whether Chinese Muslims' viewpoint is put in to the discourse about the reality that is fundamentalist / radical Islam is moot. Chinese Huis are not about to get the same degree of column-space (or air time) that the petro-dollar driven Wahhabis have gotten since the 1960s (courtesy the Saudis).

In the end the two most things count here are money and authenticity. Neither is lacking in the Saudi versions, Saudi monies and the authenticity given to an interpretation coming out of the cradle of Islam is not going to help the cause of the other native (mostly syncretic and definitely more tolerant and less violent) versions of Islam out there. There are any number of versions aside from the Wahhabi version out there that should be mainstream rational thought in Islamic societies. And all these are secondary to the original (and historically documented) violent nature of Islam itself and its propounder.

And lastly, the Zarathustras, Buddhas, Jesuses, any number of Hindu saints, etc. never had to actually murder adversaries to spread their spiritual ideals, something Muhammad had to do (in a battle field or otherwise). Therein lies a crucial reason why Islam is prone to violence. The Muslims' prophet actually encouraged lethal violence in his words and actions. The reality is out there for all to see in the preponderance of violence in even majority Muslim societies.

"I hold it that a little rebellion now and then is a good thing, and as necessary in the political world as storms in the physical." Thomas Jefferson.

I suspect the rest of this story is that more low paid workers are laid off, their work tasks are push on to other low paid workers who end up doing 1 and 1/2 or 2 jobs of the pay of only one. The remaining workers are bullied and threatened, so many accept pay freezes and reduced benefits to avoid unemployment themselves. Morale suffers, and quality of work declines while extra fees are added for customers. Aren't some banks now charging to interact with a human? The prime objective of management becomes self-reward and self-glorification. I suspect this is happening not only in financial services, but in education, airlines, communications, and industry after industry. And still too many believe Romney, de-regulation, and trickle down economies are something different.
This seems to basically sum it up.

Right on! Gotta give Barry credit for breaking that stranglehold of Big Business on American life by throwing all those banksters into the slammer. Oh wait... he's actually printing an ADDIDIONAL $40 BILLION A MONTH to hand over to them.

"But Romney isn’t running for re-election, and this was a case where merely seeming forward-looking, energetic and reassuring was enough to remind Americans of all the ways that the Obama era has disappointed them – and in so doing, sent shivers down liberalism’s glass jaw."

Bad wording, Mr. Douthat. Should be: "sent shivers down liberalism's spine." The more important thing is: nobody - even a naive liberal - believes that a second Obama term is going to lead us to the Promised Land. But his administration will try to make things better for the working and middle classes. The Republican alternative is a regime that will solidify the stranglehold of Big Business on American life.
As a parent trying to figure out what to do with my 8 -year old son, I really appreciate your thoughts. It means a lot to me. Thank you for sharing this.
Agreed. And I also wonder whether the parents would be so keen to keep their children on all this medication long-term if they had to pay for it themselves.
That's the first thing I noticed, too. I've been on Risperdal and that's exactly what I looked like while on the drug.

The attitude of the physician quoted in this article chills me to the bone. Medicating a child with Risperdal when his "psychotic symptoms" were clearly not intrinsic to him, but were brought on by another drug? Unbelievable.

I have personal experience with Risperdal; it was prescribed to me (as an adult, by a psychiatrist) as part of my treatment for a major depressive episode some years ago. Even the smallest dose rendered me completely unable to think, to process and synthesize information, to write coherently, or to remember the multiple appointments and responsibilities I had during the course of a single working day. Withdrawal was far worse; in spite of efforts to taper it off gradually, I became floridly psychotic, something I had not been prior to the medication (I was simply profoundly depressed). It took a two-week stay in a private psychiatric hospital before I felt like "myself" again. I cannot believe such a dangerous substance would be used so casually with a child.

Well, it was either Rope a Dope, or simply a bad performance. Going on the principal of Occam's Razor (i.e.  the simpler answer is more likely correct), I suspect it was the latter. Still, it all comes down to Ohio, and at the end of the day, I suspect that the voters there aren't going to vote for Mitt "let the auto industry go bankrupt" Romney. Even so, as an Obama supporter, things are too close for comfort at the moment.

It never ceases to amaze me how easy it is to blame others for one's own shortcomings.  Where are the sensible Greek voices prompting the Greek people to recognize that they are architects of their own misery? What did they expect would be the consequence of their profligate spending and endemic corruption?!!

I am a brahmin and do think that reservation system should continue but it needs a review. Ideally it needs 3 to 4 changes that would go a long way in setting things right but no political party will have guts or support to work these changes.

There is one sweeping change that can remediate 60 to 70 percent of ills in the current system and the political party that does it will benefit too, so should be doable. That one sweeping change will be to reserve 50% of all seats in reserved categories to below poverty line candidates. This one change will ensure that percolation of benefits in backward castes increases at the same time allowing time social changes to happen as other 50 does go to other candidates in the same caste/category.

Other changes that should be done but have no benefit for political parties
Reservations should not be more than 50%
Poor from forward castes and minorities should have access to reservations (but as it is already 50% so politically suicidal to redistribute)

The reason for my support is the higher education in most government colleges in India is highly subsidized so should be for only intelligent few or for some social purpose(nor is it sustainable). Governments should not be deciding who and what should be useful and it is best for market to decide. Government's role should be of enabler of private education and guardian of student's interest . I can proudly say that I have not taken a Rupee of government for education and happy for it.
The idea that the caste system survives in any form in India is disgraceful.  Do they still burn widows in this enlightened nation?

This is not Yoga in the real sense, this is just some facial exercises or movements ,that may or may not help. I cannot understand why people abuse the word "yoga" , it actually means union of your soul with the divinity. It looks like you can call anything "yoga" if you want to sell something nowadays.

90% of corrupt money ($2 trillion) in India is with forward caste people
http://goo.gl/H74Bp

Their population is less than 150 million
http://goo.gl/r6GKy

Swami Vivekananda did not belong to any political party, he had a universal message based on Vedanta appealing to all people,any party, religion or nationality. These political parties are exploiting his name to their advantage.
